Geometric structures based on such crystals increase the freedom to manipulate electromagnetic wave, giving 2D materials infinite vitality. Recently, micro–nano devices integrated with patterned graphene, MXenes, MoS2, WS2, or black phosphorus are refreshing human being’s cognition, pushing micro–nano devices into a new
level.[19–24] However, there is still broad space for improvement. Designing a high-performance micro–nano device remains a great challenge. Selecting materials based on the intrinsic nature, arranging layout, tailoring patterned structures, choosing fabrication methods, as well as knowing physical mechanism of devices are all key links in designing a prominent device.
Intellectualization, multifunction, automation, or high integration is an inevitable trend in various devices. Reasonable utilization of physical effects to improve performance, optimize figure of merit, and integrate multiple functionalities are becoming the theme of micro–nano devices. Herein, we start from the crystal and electronic structures of several typical 2D materials to summarize the available physical effects and electromagnetic response behaviors. We highlight the progress in preparing patterned 2D materials, and emphasize the mechanism of the micro–nano devices to broaden the horizons for designing devices. Finally, we predict future directions of fabrication techniques and point out the problems in current devices.

sections.heading: 2. Electronic Structures and Available Physical Effects of a 2D Crystal
sections.text:
Crystal and electronic structures codetermine the properties of materials. Crystal structure, including constituent elements, arrangement of atoms, bonding manner, and stacking order of layers, directly dominates the electronic properties of 2D materials, such as the density of state (DOS), charge density, difference, etc. This then directly results in various electromagnetic functions of 2D materials.
2D materials strongly drive the development of micro–nano devices, and patterned structures based on such crystals bring new opportunities. The advanced fabrication techniques of patterned 2D materials and the analysis of their electronic structures, and physical properties to provide access to diverse applications are discussed. Special attention is given to the hotspot electromagnetic functions and devices based on patterned 2D materials, including photodetectors, optoelectronic switches, modulators, polarization converters, gratings, as well as electromagnetic wave attenuation devices. Finally, a systematical outlook on the development of patterned 2D materials in micro–nano devices is presented, pointing out the current problems and exploring the most promising directions in the future.

sections.heading: 2.1. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene, single layer graphite, shows a honeycomb crystal lattice composed of carbon (C) atoms with sp2-hybridized, as shown in Figure 1a1. Each C atom has four outer electrons that occupy three 2sp2 orbitals and one 2p orbital, respectively. Electrons in 2sp2 orbitals are firmly bonded with that of adjacent three C atoms via in-plane σ bonds, benefiting the robustness of the structure. The CC bond length is 0.142 nm. The residual electron in 2p orbital forms a out-plane delocalized π bond, contributing to high mobility and high electrical conductivity. Figure 1a2 shows the corresponding Brillouin zone with Dirac cones, linear energy band structure, located in K and K′ points. The crossed energy band means that graphene is a zero bandgap semiconductor with a measured mobility of 15 000 cm2 V−1 s−1.[25,26]
Recently, researchers devoted themselves to developing bandgap tailoring method of graphene for the purpose of broadening the applications of graphene in electronic devices. There are at least six possible methods: i) Chemical doping.[27] Nonequivalent element will break the in-plane symmetry of graphene lattice, resulting in the opening of π–π* bandgap. For example, BN doping can broaden the bandgap of few-layer graphene to 600 meV, and N doping can bring out 200 meV bandgap of single-layer graphene.[28,29] ii) Variation of edge structure. Edge structures of nanometer-sized graphene, zigzag and armchair, greatly influence its bandgap. Since bandgaps of graphene with armchair edges originate from edge effects and quantum confinement, and gaps of graphene with zigzag edges arise from a staggered sublattice potential, the ratio of zigzag edges to armchair edges dominates the electric structure of graphene.[30,31] Ritter and Lyding demonstrated that the bandgap of a graphene nanoribbon with armchair edges in higher fraction is larger than that of a ribbon with predominantly zigzag edges at similar width.[32] iii) Tailoring lateral dimensions. Bandgaps of graphene nanoribbons with zigzag edges or armchair edges all decrease when the widths increase, which proves the ability of crystal engineering for tailoring the energy gap.[33–35] For example, 2.3 nm wide graphene nanoribbons with zigzag edges exhibit a larger bandgap (0.14 eV) than the 3.3 nm wide ribbon (0.12 eV).[32] iv) External electric-field modulation.[36,37] The external electric-field modulation can break the inversion symmetric of AB stacking graphene, thus tuning its bandgap. Zhang et al. demonstrated that the bandgap of the AB staked bilayer graphene can be opened as high as 250 meV by individually controlling top or bottom gate.[38] v) Strain engineering.[39–41] For example, the bandgap of graphene can be opened up to 300 meV when the uniaxial tensile strain is 1%. vi) Controlling stacking orders of few-layer graphene. Different stacking orders and interlayer interactions of graphene are able to cause the π band splitting.[42] All above methods pave the way for graphene band engineering, so that the patterned graphene provides a viable way for designing electric devices.
Defects from the atomic vacancy, rotation of bonds, and functional groups are unavoidable (Figure 1a3), which may change the hybrid orbital of C atoms. Defects will create scattering centers that decrease the transfer efficiency of electrons.[43] For graphene, electrons are able to transport a submicrometer distance

sections.heading: 2.2. MXenes
sections.text:
MXenes, transition metal carbides, nitrides, or carbonitrides, are emerging 2D materials. In MXenes, early transition metals sandwich C and/or N, i.e., they arrange in the form of [MX]nM with n from 1 to 3. M is short for early transition metals such as Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, etc. X represents C, N, or both. MXenes are obtained from MAX by etching A, i.e., a III or IV A group element. For example, Mo2CTx is achieved by etching Ga from Mo2Ga2C, as shown in Figure 1b1.[56] Tx represents the

surface terminations such as O, F, and OH. The highresolution scanning transmission electron microscope (HRSTEM) images of Mo2TiAlC2 (MAX) and Mo2TiC2Tx (MXene) flakes are compared in Figure 1b2.[57]
MXenes exhibit diverse electronic properties covering metallic and semiconducting. Different surface terminations are able to switch between metallic and semiconducting behaviors. For example, Xie and Kent demonstrated all Ti2C(Tx) and Ti2N(Tx) monolayers but Ti2CO2 are metallic.[58] The electronic properties of MXenes are dominated by MM d-orbitals in outer layers, e.g., MoMo d-orbitals for Mo2TiC2 and TiTi d-orbitals for Ti3C2.[57]
Tailoring of MXenes to nanoribbons is another method for tuning the bandgap. Different from semiconducting Ti2CO2 monolayer as mentioned above, zigzag-edge and armchair-edge Ti2CO2 nanoribbons have the band structures that vary with width.[59] In Figure 1b3, both asymmetric and symmetric armchair Ti2CO2 nanoribbons present semiconducting behavior with an opened bandgap. However, zigzag nanoribbons own a widthdependent bandgap with the electronic properties ranging from semiconductors to metals (Figure 1b4), promising for multifunctional electronic devices. Thus, tailoring the chirality and width are valid strategy to engineer electronic properties of MXenes.
The effect of surface terminations on the electronic transport properties of Ti3C2 is compared by Berdiyorov.[60] With F and OH, Ti3C2 samples present extended electronic states, indicating larger electron transport properties, while pristine Ti3C2 and Ti3C2 with O have localized electronic states that reduce the probability of electrons passing. Electrostatic-potential is also a considerable factor for electron transport. The potential oscillation of oxide is the largest, leading to the increase of electron scattering not conducive to electron transport as well. Due to different constituent elements, thus the different conductivities, one needs to choose the right types of MXenes according to the functions of different devices.
Since atomic defects are prevalent in 2D materials, MXenes are no exception. Figure 1b2 shows two adjacent Ti vacancies from the same sublayer.[61] Sang et al. demonstrated that defects do not strongly affect the conductivity of Ti3C2Tx monolayer by the calculated DOS and experimental results. In general, the electrical properties of MXenes depend on not only the nature of chemical elements, but the surface functional groups, geometry, width, etc.
Crystal and electronic structures of MXenes provide the available physical effects. For example, the conductivity of Ti3C2Tx is thickness-dependent.[62] When increasing thickness of a Ti3C2Tx sheet, the conductivity rises, thus the surface plasmon intensity.[63] By tailoring the structure of Ti3C2Tx sheets, polarization is improved to facilitate electromagnetic attenuation.[64] Thus, a thermoelectric generator is achieved by sufficiently using electromagnetic energy.

sections.heading: 2.3. MoS2 and WS2
sections.text:
MoS2 or WS2 monolayer consists of three atomic layers with the configuration of S–Mo(W)–S, where two S atomic layers are separated by a metal layer, as shown in Figure 1c1.[65] S and Mo(W) atoms are bonded by covalence, while multilayer
MoS2 or WS2 is stacked by weak van der Waals forces. They have different polymorphs including 1T, 2H, and 3R, where “1,” “2,” and “3” denote the numbers of MoS2 or WS2 monolayer per unit cell, and “T,” “H,” and “R” are individually short for trigonal, hexagonal, and rhombohedral symmetries, respectively.[66,67] In polymorphs, 2H is the most stable one. 2H-MoS2 and 2H-WS2 both have thickness-dependent electronic structures. Monolayer MoS2 and WS2 are semiconductors with direct bandgaps near 2 eV (Figure 1c4).[65] Bilayer MoS2 and WS2 become indirect semiconductors with smaller bandgaps. For bulk MoS2 and WS2, the indirect bandgaps reduce to 1.2 and 1.3 eV, respectively. Such change in bandgap testifies that there is coupling effect between the layers. However, their optical direct gaps located at K point do not change with the thickness, and the values are comparable to the optical direct bandgap of bulk sample. Experimentally, Terrones’s group demonstrated the bandgap transition of WS2 by photoluminescence (PL) spectra.[68] The PL intensity is high in the region of WS2 monolayer and then weakens with increased layers, supported by the transition from direct gap at K point in monolayer to indirect gap in the bulk. Thus, MoS2 and WS2 are often developed as optical devices. Furthermore, different from graphene with the prominent electronic properties associated with hybridization of 2s and 2p orbitals, the electronic structures of MoS2 and WS2 are mainly dominated by the 4d orbitals of Mo and W.
Polymorphs have distinct electronic structures. Different from semiconducting 2H-MoS2, 1T-MoS2 is metallic.[69] Using the characteristics of different electronic structures, two or more phases can be arranged in order to satisfy specific function, that is, different phases are able to form a patterned material or a device at atomic precision. For example, a Schottky diode composed of 2H and 1T phases is shown in Figure 1c2, realized by doping with 0.6 at% Re and providing thermal activation energy under electron-beam irradiation.[70] Two phases with different contrasts in annular dark-field images are easy to distinguish.
Experimentally, the mobility of monolayer MoS2 is at least 200 cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperature.[71] The temperaturedependent mobility decreases with the rise of temperature due to phonon scattering.[72] Defect provides a means of regulating the electron transport. For MoS2 with no defects, electron density is periodic with band-like electron transport. For MoS2 with S vacancies, electrons are localized, where electron transport is governed by hopping.[73] Hong et al. confirmed that antisite defects, especially one Mo atom replacing one S atom, are common for physical vapour deposition (PVD) (Figure 1c3).[74] The mobility can be reduced by 3 times through defect-induced localized discrete bands. In general, both vacancies and antisites serving as the electron scattering centers forcefully but overwhelmingly affect the mobility.
Due to the diversity of electronic structures, available physical effects of MoS2 are different. For example, there is a limitation on generating tunable plasmons in intrinsic 2H-MoS2 for the relatively low carrier density, so a phase transition to 1T may needed.[75] The details are specified in Section 4.1. The features of MoS2 or WS2, direct bandgap of monolayer and indirect bandgap of multilayer, are favorable to develop photoelectric devices. Furthermore, defects in MoS2 impact on not only the bandgap, but also the partial charge density in which permittivity property is influenced.[76–78]

sections.heading: 2.4. Black Phosphorus
sections.text:
As an allotrope of phosphorus, black phosphorus monolayer consists of folded honeycomb structure, with the armchair and zigzag arrangements along two directions, as shown in
Figure 1d1, resulting in anisotropic electrical properties.[79,80] Different from graphene, each P atom with three valence electrons bonds with three adjacent atoms. There is no extra valence electron. Thus, black phosphorus is a semiconductor with a direct bandgap. Multilayer black phosphorus is stacked by weak van der Waals forces like transition metal dichalcogenides.
Black phosphorus features anisotropic electronic structures and layer-dependent direct bandgaps. As shown in Figure 1d2, the bandgap falls rapidly with the number of layers increasing, finally reaching 0.36 eV for the bulk.[81] Particularly, the bandgap of monolayer black phosphorus is 1.51 eV. For bilayer black phosphorus, the gap value becomes 1.02 eV. The descending bandgap derives from additional dispersed (valence/conduction) bands caused by the interlayer interaction, i.e., wavefunction overlap instead of van der Waals force.
The mobility of black phosphorus is anisotropic associated with the electronic structure. A high hole mobility is demonstrated from 600 cm2 V−1 s−1 of monolayer to 4000 cm2 V−1 s−1 of five layer.[81] Zhang et al. observed the surface structure of black phosphorus via scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), as shown in Figure 1d3.[82] A vacancy defect in the white circle can induce the charge redistribution, which affects the electronic transport property of black phosphorus.
The anisotropic electronic structures of black phosphorus will produce anisotropic plasmonic dispersion, which enhances the effect of electromagnetic response.[83] This feature makes black phosphorus a promising candidate in electromagnetic attenuation devices and photodetectors by rational design of its crystal direction.[84,85]

sections.heading: 3. Fabrication of Patterned 2D Materials
sections.text: Fabrication methods determine the structure and thus the properties of a 2D material. The ability to construct nano/microscale or even millimeter patterns is extremely desirable to fabricate 2D functional materials for micro/nanodevices. Precise location and tailoring at the atomic scale of 2D materials are able to tune the physical properties. Although there are diverse preparation methods, high-precision and large-scale processing method is always a challenge.[86,87] Here, we take some methods as examples, including bottom-up fabrication such as self-assembly, plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and site-selective growth, as well as top-down fabrication such as helium ion beam technology, nanoimprint lithography, inkjet printing, screen printing, electron beam lithography, and nanosphere lithography, as shown in Figure 2.[86,88,89,100]

sections.heading: 3.1. Helium Ion Beam Technology
sections.text:
Helium ion beam is a top-down technique that etches patterns from continuous 2D films, as shown in Figure 3a.[88] As a gas ion source, its energy resolution is smaller than other metal ion
beams, such as gallium, and its de Broglie wave is considerably smaller than that of electron, giving a resolution of 0.5 nm.[90] Therefore, helium ion beam is utilized to the precise control of line width, crystal structure, and edge roughness.
Helium ion beam is extremely suitable for 2D materials, due to the presence of subsurface damage inside thick materials, as shown in Figure 3b.[91] In 2009, Marcus’s group achieved an etched channel with a minimum width of 10 nm in suspended graphene device by helium ion beam.[92] Then, Abbas et al. improved the channel width to 5 nm, and solved the difficulties of uniformity, alignment, and high aspect ratios.[93] Such uniform graphene nanoribbon arrays can serve as a detector for sensing NO2 gas through conductance change. In recent years, a smaller width of 1 nm was realized on MoS2 (Figure 3c).[94] However, vacancies and amorphization are unavoidable under He+ collisions, limiting the applications of patterned 2D materials.[95] Zhang’s group confined the amorphous region to 1 nm, fabricating a 7 nm width MoS2 nanoribbon with intact crystal structure (Figure 3d), with a beam current of 1.00 pA, a pixel pitch of 1 nm, and a dwell time of 3–5 ms per pixel.[94] This patterning technology can be extended to other 2D nanomaterials. For example, Mn2O3 was milled into an array of 10 nm wide nanoribbons in Figure 3e.
Besides forming patterns on few-layer 2D materials, the ultrafine helium ion beam can selectively introduce point defects or ions to modify the crystal structure so as to alter the physical properties (Figure 3f). Nakaharai et al. used He+ beam to tune the conduction properties of graphene by controllably introducing low-density point defects from 0.2 to 1.3%.[96] As shown in Figure 3g, ID decays, as defect density increases

For MoS2, He+ ions preferentially sputter S rather than Mo, so the stoichiometry of MoS2 is controlled. By strengthening the He+ ion dose, the resistivity of MoS2 is divided into four regions. As shown in Figure 3h, MoS2 presents semiconducting behavior at a dose of ≈1014 He+ per cm2, where the defects gradually appear. When the dose is increased to ≈1015 He+ per cm2, MoS2 possesses insulating behavior, where the disordered domains in amorphous MoS2 occur. The greater He+ doses will generate more vacancy defects resulting in amorphous regions. At the dose of ≈1017 He+ per cm2, metallic-like behavior appears, where the proportion of Mo atoms is enhanced. Finally, when the dose of He+ is up to 1018 He+ per cm2, the excessive He+ doses remove MoS2.
Obviously, helium ion beam technology is a precise method to form patterns on 2D materials, and has the ability to locally manipulate the electronic properties of materials. However, it does not apply to the large-scale processing in view of its efficiency.

sections.heading: 3.2. Self-Assembly Method
sections.text:
Self-assembly means the structural units, such as atoms, molecules, nanomaterials, or other elements, organize and aggregate spontaneously through noncovalent bonds or other interaction force to form an ordered stable structure, as shown in Figure 4a.
It is a parallel processing system where all elements organize concurrently. The main factors that determine the morphology of the organization relate to unit recognition, component structure, units’ number, and solvent environment. Large scale selfassembly paves the way toward novel nanometric patterned 2D materials, holding promise for device applications.
Molecular precursor, C38Br2N4H22, can polymerize to form an isolated and long graphene nanoribbon by dehalogenation, as shown in Figure 4c.[97] If the molecular precursor is doped with N atoms, self-assembly will occur between the adjacent graphene nanoribbons, where N atoms will induce adjacent graphene nanoribbons to spontaneously align into 2D arrays by H-bonding (Figure 4b). There are dislocations when the nanoribbons are arranged laterally, which arise from the match of lone pair of N with the CH moieties (Figure 4d). Hence, the edge-to-edge ribbon arrays are coordinated by covalent and hydrogen bonds (Figure 4e). Practically, in solution, a 3D crystalline structure can be built from sheets of edge-to-edge nanoribbons via π-stacking and van der Waals forces. It is noted that the individual nanoribbon will determine the optoelectronic properties of the assembled crystal.
Recently, Camilli et al. employed self-assembly technology to fabricate highly uniform graphene nanodot arrays, as shown in Figure 4f.[98] It is a challenge to epitaxially embed uniform dots with the size of 1.6 ± 0.2 nm in a 2D B–C–N alloy. The competition of dot-boundary energy and moiré-modulated substrate interaction makes it possible. The array order is dominated by long-range repulsion among the dots. And the C concentration in the system affects the period length of the array. Thus, the

Joung et al. reported a micro/ nanoscale self-folding graphene-based cube by surface tension forces of the polymer.[99] As shown in Figure 4h, six graphene squares on protection layers are fabricated. Photolithography technology is used to remove unwanted graphene, and pattern metal, semiconductor, or insulator on the faces. By heating the 2D membrane up to the polymer’s melting point in water, the polymer starts to melt, generating a surface tension force to induce self-assembling (Figure 4i). After self-assembly, protection layers are removed, which protect intrinsic properties of graphene during the complete process. Finally, hollow, self-folding, and polyhedral graphene structures are achieved. The advantages of this method are as follows: i) protection layers protect graphene’s inherent properties; ii) decoration of metal or other material patterns will induce novel properties. More importantly, this methodology could be easily extended to other 2D materials such as MXenes, transition metal dichalcogenides, and black phosphorus.

sections.heading: 3.3. Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition
sections.text:
Plasma enhanced CVD is a technique that a source gas is ionized to form a plasma. With an appropriate amount of reactive material introduced, plasma discharge is used to activate the reactive material and realize CVD (Figure 5a).[100] Compared
with traditional CVD technique, plasma contains abundant high-energy electrons, which can provide the activation energy in reaction system. Plasma sources are divided into radio frequency, dc and microwave plasma.
Originally, plasma is adopted to provide a platform for selfassembly of uniformly vertical graphene nanowalls. Under radiofrequency plasma with a discharge power of 1.0 kW, graphene grows vertically rather than deposition on the entire surface of the nanopore alumina membrane, as shown in Figure 5b.[100] Tips or sharp edges of the membrane as growth sites promote nucleation under the heating effect of plasma (Figure 5c). Similarly, gold-treated alumina membranes are able to perform this function, where gold nanoparticles function as catalyst. The presence of gold nanoparticles allows tailoring the quality, growth density, and edge length of graphene. The prepared graphene walls are uniform, with height changing from 1.5 to 2 µm at two pore sizes of 25 and 60 nm. This indicates that the morphology of graphene nanowall is weakly dependent on the pore size, so this technique can be extended to more 2D materials with various pores.
Different from radio-frequency plasma CVD above, Yu et al. reported a direct current plasma-enhanced CVD method to assemble a patterned vertical graphene nanowall.[101] They improved the control method by patterning gold electrodes as letters U, W, and M with a thickness of 50 nm and a width of 1–5 µm, on SiO2/Si substrate (Figure 5d). Grounded U and M are connected to the network, while the isolated W is floating. In the reactor, introducing water vapor, Ar, and CH4 (or C2H2) flows provides reaction atmosphere and carbon source. Under direct current plasma, the electric field above the gold strip is much higher than that above the substrate due to the efficient ionization of the gas. This manifests that graphene nanosheets are able to grow on the gold strip instead of the substrate in

sections.heading: 3.4. Nanoimprint Lithography
sections.text:
Among nanopatterning methods of 2D materials, nanoimprint lithography is a mechanical method that satisfies industrial integration to produce large-scale micro or nano arrays. It features low cost and high throughput. Besides the template resolution, there are many factors that affect the final pattern resolution, such as the nature of 2D materials and the imprint time.
Figure 6a shows the fabrication process of the graphene nanomesh by thermal nanoimprint.[102] Monolayer or bilayer graphene is first electrically printed onto a Si substrate. A polystyrene layer as the imprint resist layer is spin-coated on the graphene films. Then the SiO2 imprint template with raised hexagonal columns is pressed on the resist layer at 120 °C for 5 min. The corresponding scanning electron microscope (SEM) of the template is shown in Figure 6b. After that, the thinner part of the resist layer, i.e., the resist residual layer thickness and graphene under the thinner part are etched in O2-based reactive ion etching using 25 sccm of O2. Finally, the resist layer is completely dissolved in a solution. The resulted graphene nanomesh is shown in Figure 6c. Different from thermal nanoimprint, Zribi et al. fabricated large area graphene nanomesh
by soft UV nanoimprint lithography.[103] During the process, monolayer or bilayer graphene films are produced on 4H-SiC (0001) by thermal decomposition. An Amonil/Ge/poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) trilayer composite is selected as a resist. The final monolayer graphene nanomesh can serve as a Hepatitis C virus biosensor due to the faster electron transfer in imprinted nanoedges. Nanoimprint is a versatile technology. Notably, polymers are usually used as resist materials. However, the residual polymer will produce vibration fingerprints, affecting experimental extinction spectra of graphene nanohole arrays, reported by Gopalan et al. They proposed that this can be eliminated by annealing.[104]
The whole imprint process of forming a pattern on a 2D material is often compatible with other typical preparation methods.[105,106] For example, Chen et al. combined nanoimprint and shear exfoliation to generate monolayer or few-layer MoS2, with the lateral feature sizes of patterned MoS2 dominating the final quality.[107] In addition, CVD, reactive ion etching, and electron beam lithography are usually assisted methods in nanoimprint lithography to grow 2D materials, remove polymeric resist, and fabricate patterned molds, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.5. Site-Selective Growth
sections.text:
Compared with top-down techniques that are limited by the etching tools, bottom-up techniques are able to overcome this shortcoming to achieve edges accurate to atoms. Site-selective growth means direct synthesis, usually via CVD, of 2D materials on prepatterned nucleation sites, such as prepatterned underlying metal layer, growth seeds, triboelectric charge patterns, etc. The prepatterned process is often addressed by other assistant methods, including lift-off technique, electron beam lithography, thermal evaporation, etc. The nucleation sites prevent materials from growing at random locations, so one can

In the earlier years, there were a lot of researches about the synthesis of graphene on metals such as Pt, Ru, and Ir.[108–110] Metal layer is the active area where graphene nucleates and grows in an atmosphere of hydrocarbon gas. Hence, prepatterned metal layer can be utilized to directly synthesize graphene patterns during CVD. As shown in Figure 7a, large-scale pattern growth of graphene was realized on preprocessed Ni.[86,111] The mobility of the graphene film is 3750 cm2 V−1 s−1, high enough to act as the electrodes. Subsequently, the graphene patterns were shrunk to micrometer-scale. Multilayer graphene or PMMA is processed by electron beam lithography to form seed arrays, where single crystal graphene nucleates and grows by employing the precursor CH4 at 1050 °C.[112,113] In Figure 7b,c, PMMA dots with a diameter of 0.8 µm and hexagonal graphene arrays with a diameter ≈10 µm on Cu surface are shown respectively.[113] However, compared with top-down techniques, such size relatively large and such arrays relatively nonuniform, Arnold and co-workers engineered uniform graphene nanoribbon arrays on

The narrower width originates from the pregrowth anneal of the seed. The synthesis is performed by deposition of flowing CH4 at 910 °C. For MoS2, a variety of seeds have been researched to synthesize MoS2 patterns. As shown in Figure 7e, “NBIC @ UPENN” patterns spelled by monolayer MoS2 flakes are achieved by deposition of S on MoO3 sites at 750 °C.[115] The transistor fabricated by such MoS2 flakes exhibits mobility up to 8.2–11.4 cm2 V−1 s−1, indicating the high material quality. Micrometre-scale Pt/Ti dots also employed to be the seeds, circular arrays are realized by deposition of MoO3 and S (Figure 7f).[116]
Recently, another two pretreatment processes enriched the research of site-selective growth. Ryu et al. explored a rubbinginduced site-selective growth strategy to produce MoS2 line patterns, where microscale triboelectric charge patterns serve as the seeds.[117] Lee et al. utilized prepatterned cross-linked 1,2,3,4-tetraphenylnapthalene to generate graphene. Meanwhile, the interfacial adhesion bonding between the SiO2 substrate and cross-linked 1,2,3,4-tetraphenylnapthalene avoids carbon source subliming completely.[118]

sections.heading: 3.6.1. Inkjet Printing
sections.text: Inkjet printing is a method through which one can print any data or patterns he wants from the computer. It is very competitive due to the features of high flexibility and noncontact. Particularly, the parameters, particles size, viscosity, and surface tension of inks dominate the pattern quality. The printable inks of materials have been researched including carbon materials, metals, conducting polymers, and ceramics.[119–121] Another point to be noted is that substrates such as Si/SiO2, polyimide, and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) may need to be treated to improve the surface wettability. For 2D materials, especially graphene, a series of studies were conducted to explore the inkjet printing strategy. With Microsoft Powerpoint, Huang et al. designed and fabricated a chemical sensor via a Hewlett-Packard Deskjet K7108 printer with graphene aqueous inks.[122] Secor et al. improved the environmentally benign graphene ink, and printed 60 µm width line arrays by a commercial Fujifilm Dimatix Materials Printer (DMP 2800), as shown in Figure 8a.[123] Li et al. developed a full printing method to fabricate micro-supercapacitors with tunable thickness on different substrates.[124] It is noted that inkjet printing is a potential technique in applications of electronics, chemistry, biotechnology, etc.

sections.heading: 3.6.2. Screen Printing
sections.text:
Screen printing is a historic printing method. A patterned hollow screen is placed on the substrate. Inks are scraped onto the surface of the hollow screen by a squeegee, and flow through the hollow patterns to the substrate. When craping a pattern, the speed of squeegee, screen mesh, and ink property predominately influence the quality of the pattern. Xu et al. reported a screen printed supercapacitor device by using graphene/polyaniline
inks.[125] Hyun et al. and Arapov et al. both achieved graphene lines with the resolution down to 40 µm and good electrical properties by screen printing during the same period.[126,127] Recently, Xu et al. fabricated a Ti3C2Tx-based microscale hybrid device with an energy density of 8.84 µWh cm−2 by two-step screen printing method (Figure 8b).[128] Obviously, screen printing is simple and a widely used technique, easily extended to other 2D materials for exploration of coplanar devices.

sections.heading: 3.6.3. Electron Beam Lithography
sections.text: Electron beam lithography is a serial processing technique. Under precise control of a computer, a focused electron beam is employed to expose the resist according to the requirements, so as to produce the regions with different solubility properties. Subsequently, development is carried out to obtain a resist pattern. Then the pattern is transferred to the material like traditional optical lithography. In contrast to light, it is not limited by diffraction limits. Ryu et al. reported graphene nanoribbons with the width of 15–100 nm by combination of electron beam lithography and oxygen plasma etching, as shown in Figure 8c.[129] Fang et al. also used electron beam lithography and oxygen plasma to produce graphene nanoribbons with a diameter of 60 nm.[24] Marques and co-workers demonstrated the dominated role of dose and exposure time of electron beam on graphene patterns.[130]

sections.text:

Due to the point contact between nanospheres and 2D materials, limited etched patterns are achieved. Obviously, the diameter of nanospheres and the distance between them seriously impact the etching patterns. Liu et al. fabricated ultranarrow graphene nanoribbons with a width of 12 nm by polystyrene nanospheres with a diameter of 1 µm, as shown in Figure 8d.[131] Zhu et al. demonstrated the shadow effect and improved nanosphere lithography.[132] Graphene dot arrays and antidot arrays are obtained by monolayer polystyrene nanospheres and bilayer close-packed polystyrene nanospheres, respectively. Wu et al. developed a new strategy, relative rotation of two stacked monolayer polystyrene nanospheres, to produce graphene moiré metasurfaces.[133]
In addition, 2D materials are not limited to graphene, Mxenes, MoS2, WS2, and black phosphorus. Metal oxides are important members in 2D materials, including rare earth metal oxide, transition metal oxide, post-transition metal oxide, etc. Beyond the conventional vapor phase growth, the use of liquid alloy solvent to make subnanometer 2D metal oxides is one of the most distinctive methods. Kalantar-Zadeh and co-workers employed gallium-based alloys as a reaction solvent to produce sub-nanometer 2D Gd2O3, HfO2, and Al2O3, where two synthetic approaches are developed.[134] The first approach is similar to the exfoliation method of graphene, that is, a substrate is used to touch the metal droplet for exfoliating outer metal oxide by van der Waals force. The other approach is injecting gas into the liquid metal. These two techniques are very interesting to efficiently synthesize thin 2D metal oxides without requiring complicated equipment. Alsaif et al. used liquid metal van der Waals transfer method to synthesize atomically thin SnO/In2O3 heterostructure photodetector. This is the first time that p–n heterostructures are achieved by liquid metal synthesis.[135]

sections.heading: 4. Electromagnetic Responses
sections.text: Crystal and electronic structures of 2D materials dominate the intrinsic properties and functions, such as conductivity and dielectric property. Here, surface plasmons and electromagnetic behaviors, as the considerable foundations for electromagnetic functions and devices, covering gigahertz to optical of 2D materials, are highlighted.

sections.heading: 4.1. Surface Plasmons
sections.text:
Surface plasmons are the collectively oscillatory free electrons triggered by electromagnetic wave, usually occurring on metal surfaces. However, the activation of
surface plasmon is not limited to metals. It has been demonstrated in 2D materials. Current researches indicate that surface plasmons can be controlled by diverse methods, including the thickness, carrier density, functionalization, and other frequency-dependent properties. Plasmon resonance frequency of 2D materials commonly investigated ranging from terahertz to ultraviolet, and there is a large space for expanding the working frequency range of each material. Particularly, patterned structures provide a new idea for modulating surface plasmons.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene, a plasmonic material, has affirmed in previous researches due to its high mobility. Chen et al. studied gatetuning of graphene plasmons by the scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscope, demonstrating that graphene-oxide-semiconductor configuration supports the propagation of surface plasmons with the plasmon wavelength (λp) of ≈200 nm.[50] As shown in Figure 9a–c, infrared scattering amplitude images display periodically oscillating fringe patterns, especially near the edge, defects, and boundaries. The fringe spacing becoming wider at the edge of graphene indicates an increase in λp, which is derived from the larger carrier

By using the same method, Chen et al. visualized localized graphene plasmons strongly dependent on the backgate voltage and permittivity of SiC substrate (εSiC).[51] As shown in Figure 9d, the interference fringe width means that λp increases with the reduced εSiC. Due to the dependence of εSiC on excitation wavelength λ0, different λ0 can provide possibility for changing λp. Electrical gating is another method to regulate plasmonic resonance. In Figure 9e, increasing gate voltage adds the carrier density and thus the Fermi energy EF, leading to increased λp. There is a forbidden area when the ratio of EF to plasmon energy (EF/EP) is ≤1, where the carrier densities are very small because of the effect of interband excitations. Thus, the function of “switching plasmons on or off” is achieved by the effect of plasmon damping.
Both the above reports realized gate-tuning of graphene plasmons in graphene-semiconductor system, which is unattainable in metal, paving the way for graphene-based devices, especially the tunable devices. The interference fringe formed close to defects and edges demonstrated that patterned structure containing many edges and corners may affect the surface plasmons, e.g., damping or edge scattering.

sections.heading: 4.1.2. MXenes
sections.text:
Since MXenes exhibit metallic-like behavior, they certainly support surface plasmons. Mauchamp et al. evidenced 2D Ti3C2Tx stacked sheets presenting tunable intense surface plasmons in the mid-infrared using high-resolution transmission electron energy-loss spectroscopy and ab initio calculations.[63] There is an inverse correlation between the surface plasmon intensity and the thickness of a sheet. Furthermore, they provided a way to manipulate the surface plasmons, that is, improving electronic structure by tailoring different surface terminations.
Inspired by this work, Alshareef’s group explored surface plasmon modes of Ti3C2Tx in near-infrared and mid-infrared regimes, by STEM combined with ultrahigh resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy.[137] In Figure 10a, triangular Ti3C2Tx flake supports longitudinal mode, transversal mode, and inherent interband transition. For longitudinal mode, in addition to the fundamental dipole mode excited at the corners (Figure 10a), there are other modes including quadrupole, hexapole, central, and ring modes (Figure 10b). Obviously, the multipolar longitudinal modes are closely related to the shape, thickness, and nodes. An extra smaller triangular Ti3C2Tx is added in the red rectangle to demonstrate that each monolayer structure possesses independent polarizability. The multipolar modes along with weak interlayer coupling are beneficial for designing MXene devices. Contrary to the geometry-dependent longitudinal mode, transversal mode and inherent interband transition are evenly distributed throughout the whole flake. The effect of surface functionalization on surface plasmons is studied by in situ heating. As temperature rises up to 500 °C, terminations of F start to desorb, so the free electron density of the MXene increases. The transversal mode shifts to higher energy loss but the inherent interband transition is invariant.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. MoS2
sections.text:
Kumar and Ahluwalia found collective plasmonic oscillations in MoS2, indicating that the surface plasmons can propagate along c-axis of monolayer MoS2.[138] Later, Andersen’s group predicted that plasmon can exist at the zigzag edge of MoS2 nanoribbon on account of the metallic edge states.[139] According to the electronic structure discussed above, stable 2H-MoS2 is a semiconductor with indirect bandgap of ≈1.2 eV for bulk and direct bandgap ≈1.9 eV for monolayer. Wang et al. induced phase transition of MoS2 from 2H to 1T by ultradoping Li to improve the

As voltage increases, photoquenching effect rises, confirming the formation of 1T metallic phase (Figure 11a). The UV–vis absorbance spectra with two plasmon resonance peaks at 380 and 714 nm correspond to the 1T and 2H phases, respectively (Figure 11b). The peak at 714 nm gradually vanishes with the enhancement of voltage. Moreover, the theoretical plasmon wavelength (denoted by dotted lines) decreases with the larger intercalated Li+.
Such tunable plasmons give 2D MoS2 a great potential in optoelectronics, photonics, and electronics. However, its low photoresponsivity reduces the efficiency of light–matter interaction. Metal nanoparticles or nanoarray, such as Au and Ag, are often integrated with MoS2 to enhance light–matter interaction.[140–142] Butun et al. demonstrated that Ag nanodisk arrays are able to vastly enhance the photoluminescence intensity of monolayer MoS2, due to the plasmon resonance coupling to the excitation and emission fields.[140] Miao et al. also revealed that MoS2 decorated with Au nanoparticles has a higher local optical field and photocurrent.[141] Later, Liu et al. analyzed the strong exciton–plasmon coupling in MoS2 decorated with Ag nanodisks via the angle-resolved differential reflectance spectra, as shown in Figure 11c,d.[142] There are three resonance types, i.e., MoS2 excitons (two yellow dashed lines), localized surface plasmon resonance of each Ag nanodisk (white dashed lines),

In addition, there are some important breakthroughs in the tunable plasmon resonance of 2D metal oxides, providing new modalities for the application of plasmon in micro–nano devices. We take MoO3 as an example. Kalantar-Zadeh and co-workers reported that the plasmon resonance wavelengths of 2D HxMoO3 nanodisks can be tuned in the range from visible to nearinfrared by intercalated H+ concentration.[143] H doping not only reduces the Mo oxidation state, but also induces a large number of free electrons. Since H2O2, a by-product of the enzymatic oxidation of glucose, causes rapid changes in the amount of H+ and modulates the free electron concentration, a large plasmonic perturbation in HxMoO3 will occur. Based on this feature, an ultrasensitive plasmonic biosensing is explored. In particular, the detection limit of glucose concentration by H1.55MoO3 is as high as 2 × 10−9 m at
410 nm. Then, Ren et al. investigated the H+-driven plasmonic properties of H0.3MoO3.[144] They discovered that H+ in acidic solution can intercalate into H0.3MoO3, and OH− in alkaline solution can extract H from H0.3MoO3. Electrons induced by H+ dopant will also be affected. Thus, the plasmonic absorption peak of H0.3MoO3 is sensitive to PH. This feature can be used to fabricate a plasmonic silicon photonic ion sensor. Surface phonon polaritons, with small optical loss and strong electromagnetic confinement, complement the applications of surface plasmon polaritons in control of light. Zheng et al. demonstrated that α-MoO3 flakes support mid-infrared hyperbolic phonon polaritons.[145] Ma et al. further explored the anisotropic propagation properties of α-MoO3 phonon polaritons.[146] The study of phonon polaritons provides plentiful potential applications for light–matter interactions, especially nano photonic devices.

sections.heading: 4.1.4. Black Phosphorus
sections.text:
Black phosphorus is characterized by the inherent anisotropy. Low et al. revealed that monolayer black phosphorus has different plasmonic dispersion along armchair and zigzag directions due to the unequal electron effective masses, i.e., mass anisotropy (ma ≠ mz).[83] A further investigation in terms of the localized surface plasmons in monolayer nanoribbon and square shaped arrays was performed by Liu and Aydin.[147] As shown in Figure 12a, plasmonic responses along armchair (blue line) and zigzag (pink) directions are distinct in farinfrared regime. The wavelength of the armchair direction is shorter than that of zigzag direction based on the mass anisotropy of black phosphorus. The wider ribbons allow the longer
wavelengths for plasmonic oscillations, applying to both directions in Figure 12c,d. In addition to width, periodicity also plays a crucial role in plasmonic oscillations on account of coupling effect between adjacent black phosphorus ribbons. Moreover, Liu et al. discovered that square shaped black phosphorus mono layer has a strong electric field confinement effect at the edges and corners (Figure 12b). And square arrays can simultaneously excite localized surface plasmons in both the directions at 45° incident polarization angle.
Therefore, geometry is a considerably effective strategy for regulating the surface plasmons of black phosphorus, useful for designing an anisotropic plasmonic device. For example, Zhang et al. demonstrated that the enhanced near-field radiative heat transfer between two layers arises from the coupling of anisotropic surface plasmon polaritons of black phosphorus.[148]

sections.heading: 4.2. Dielectric Properties
sections.text: This section focuses on the dielectric properties of 2D materials, which are dominated by their crystal and electronic structures. It is an important parameter from materials to functional devices, especially the electromagnetic devices. It controls the energy conversion, extent of heat generation, as well as optical property of the materials and devices.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. MXenes
sections.text:
Dielectric properties of delaminated Ti3C2Tx nanosheet were studied by Cao’s group, as shown in Figure 15a–d.[62] Due to the competition of conduction loss and polarization loss, ε″ is codetermined by εc″ and εp″. Conduction loss is derived from the electrons transport in conductive networks constructed by contacting or stacking Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. Thus, when the concentration increases, the electron transport becomes easy
due to the smaller distance between the nanosheets. Meanwhile, the contribution of polarization cannot be ignored, because MXene with larger surface groups, defects, and functional groups introduces the asymmetry distribution of electrons to produce dipole polarization. The results demonstrate that atomic layer tailoring of the structure can be used to modulate the dielectric properties of MXenes.
Different from that in gigahertz regime, complex permittivity in higher regimes has unique mechanisms. For example, Chaudhuri et al. investigated the complex permittivity of Ti3C2Tx in the range from visible to near-infrared light.[151] They used a variable-angle spectroscopic ellipsometry setup to measure the permittivity of Ti3C2Tx with different thicknesses of 30 and 400 nm. As shown in Figure 15e,f, a crossover from dielectric to metallic properties of ε′ is observed at ≈1070 nm, confirming the presence of surface plasmon polaritons. The shorter crossover wavelength of the thicker one means getting closer to metallic properties. The large ε″ of both are related to the inherent interband transitions and carriers scattering. In order to achieve desired property, the MXene film was made into a nanodisk array, as shown in Figure 15g,h. The MXene nanodisk array with strong tunable localized surface plasmon resonance can enhance scattering, thus improving energy conversion efficiency.

Two relaxation peaks appearing in ε″ are due to the dipole polarization arising from vacancy defects of Mo and S atoms. Compared with MoS2 bulk, ε′ and ε″ of nanosheets are higher. The aggressive exfoliation process creates more defects on the surface of MoS2-NS, resulting in higher relaxation peaks. The loading content from 30 to 60 wt% represents enhancive opportunities for establishing the conductive paths.

sections.heading: 4.2.4. Black Phosphorus
sections.text: Black phosphorus is semiconductor with an adjustable direct bandgap that depends on the thickness and number of layers. Ultrathin black phosphorus has advantages in optoelectronic or photonic devices. Its permittivity is also proportional to thickness, finally saturating toward the bulk value, because of the increased surface-to-volume ratio and the lower ε of the outer layers.[152] Lu et al. studied the permittivity of the structure consisting of double black phosphorus monolayers in infrared regime by semi-classical Drude model.[153] Two sheets are placed separately at a distance with armchair and zigzag edges along z-axis and x-axis, respectively. Thus, ε are different in two directions due to the mass anisotropy which is mentioned above. ε′ of both directions are negative and ε″ are extremely large. In addition, such black phosphorus sheets are able to support transverse magnetic plasmonic waves.

sections.heading: 5. Patterned 2D Materials for Electromagnetic Functional Devices
5.1. Electromagnetic Attenuation Devices
sections.text:
Electromagnetic attenuation devices hold the balance in national defense security, human health protection, and prevention of electromagnetic wave interference in industrial equipment. Patterned 2D materials, especially fabricated on flexible substrates, are the up-and-coming generation of electromagnetic attenuation devices, including electromagnetic absorbing and shielding devices.
Tan’s group designed a series of transparent attenuation films.[154,155] As shown in Figure 17a,b, graphene is combined with transparent dielectric and metal networks to improve electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding performance.[155] The insertion of the metal networks reduces the surface resistance of the graphene hybrid film from 813.27 to 5.53 Ω sq−1, and the maximum shielding effectiveness (SE) of the Ku and Ka band is 23.6 dB.
The structure composed of graphene and polyaniline nanorod arrays has robust electromagnetic wave absorbing capacity with the maximum reflection loss (RL) of −45.1 dB.[150] As shown in Figure 17c,d, RL of the structure is greatly improved compared with that of graphene. In addition to the unique structure of nanorod arrays, the modified charge transport and enhanced relaxation (discussed in Section 4.2) are the main causes of high absorption.
Compared with traditional materials, one superiority of patterned materials is the reverse design process, i.e., one can customize materials according to the required parameters and performance. Chen et al. analyzed the optimal resistance and reactance values of graphene based on transmission line model with the reflection coefficient S11 satisfying |S11| = 0.[156] The optimal values can be used to guide the design of patterned

Based on this, the authors designed Jerusalem cross-shaped graphene arrays, where graphene first grew on the prepatterned nickel foils, then transferred onto a polyvinyl chloride or copper foil-backed FR4 substrate. Experimentally, two distinct absorption peaks are around 10.5 and 20.2 GHz. Equivalent resistance and reactance match with the optimal values (Ropt/Xopt) on both sides of the panels. The absorption mechanisms of these two bands are attributed to the different resonance modes. At lower frequency, the horizontal patches dominate the absorption, because surface current easily transits the narrow ribbon between the vertical patches, difficult to form resonance. At higher frequency, selfinductance can induce reverse current on the vertical narrow ribbon. Patches in both orientations are responsible for the absorption.
MXene is an emerging material, and its researches in the field of patterned materials are just beginning, especially in micro–nano devices. A hybridized patterned structure based on Ti3C2Tx MXene with the function of shielding THz electromagnetic wave was achieved by drop-casting method.[21] MXene colloidal solution is drop-cast onto nano slot antenna arrays to form an ultrathin MXene, constructing a hybridized material in Figure 18. SE of the structure rises rapidly over 20 dB with increasing thickness and then tends to be gentle. Choi et al.
considered that the SE is associated to strong localization of THz field and magnified refractive index in near-field region. Cai and co-workers fabricated an ultralight Ti3C2-MXene aerogel with a density of <10 mg cm−3 by a freeze-casting route.[157] The MXene internal pores with a diameter of 20 µm are achieved by using ice template, which will be removed during the freeze– dying process. They compared the SE of three MXene aerogels with densities of 6.26, 12.5, and 20.7 mg cm−3, and all of them are over 50 dB. In particular, for the MXene aerogel with a density of 20.7 mg cm−3, the maximal EMI SE is up to 75 dB in GHz range.
Plasmonic resonance plays an important role in devices. In particular, black phosphorus has unique anisotropic plasmonic resonances due to the mass anisotropy along armchair and zigzag directions. However, resonant intensities of the monolayer black phosphorus nanodisk arrays are weak at low doping.[84] Hong et al. employed graphene, which has one strong plasmonic resonance peak, to intensify the resonance of monolayer black phosphorus. The graphene–black phosphorus bilayer structure combines the asset of each material, showing two powerful and anisotropic peaks. By taking this advantage, two perfect absorbers were simulated. A graphene–black phosphorus bilayer structure with periodic gold nanoparticles on top is designed, where the plasmon resonances are excited by gold nanoparticles to achieve high anisotropic absorption. sections.heading: 5.2. Detectors
sections.text:
A graphene-based photodetector is designed in Figure 19a.[158] Ti/ Au finger plasmonic nanostructure is combined with graphene to construct p–n junction area, inducing stronger photovoltaic signals. Compared with the graphene photodetector without the nanostructure, the measured photovoltage of patterned photo detector is greatly enhanced by 20 times. The finger nanostructure effectively converts visible or near-infrared light into plasmonic oscillations, enhancing localized electric field in the p–n junction area, where blue represents 0 µV and red stands for 20 µV (Figure 19b). Besides the enhanced optical field, the maximum photovoltage at the tips is demonstrated that originates from the large electron band bending. Additionally, responses of the device can be tailored by the structure geometries through coupling with different polarization and wavelength.
Due to the tunable Fermi level of graphene (Gr), Tan et al. explored an ultrathin Gr–WS2–Gr photodetector array with the light-modulated and electrostatic gating-modulated photoresponsivity.[159] Graphene electrodes with a certain gap are fabricated to connect with the metallic bond pads on a chip. A PMMA film with randomly distributed WS2 crystals was then transferred onto the treated chip, as shown in Figure 20a. Considering the random distribution of WS2 as well as the sufficiently effective graphene coverage, not all devices can operate effectively. In Figure 20b, the device where WS2 acts as a bridge between the graphene electrodes is photodetector. It can be seen that the production process has the potential to be further improved. Both graphene and WS2 are grown by employing CVD method. Thus, monolayer and bilayer WS2 sheets coexist, which is a factor that affects device performance. The photoluminescence signal of Gr–WS2–Gr device can be used to judge the layer number of WS2. When the layer number increases from one to two, the direct bandgap will convert to indirect, resulting in a reduced emission. In Figure 20c, the photocurrent

Importantly, there are four important figures of merit for evaluating the performance of photodetectors including photoresponsivity, external quantum efficiency, photogain, and specific detectivity. As shown in Figure 20d, under a fixed incident power density, photoresponsivity is affected by the layer number, channel length, and source–drain voltage (Vds). The maximum photoresponsivity under 5 V bias is more than 2.5 and 3.5 A W−1 for monolayer and bilayer WS2 devices, respectively. And the corresponding external quantum efficiency can be up to 583% and 933% for monolayer and bilayer devices. Since monolayer WS2 possesses direct bandgap, the photogain of monolayer is estimated to be 73, larger than that of bilayer (53). Specific detectivity characterizing sensitivities of photodetector are 9.9 × 1010 and 1.6 × 1010 Jones for monolayer and bilayer devices, respectively. The tunable photoresponsivity
is presented in Figure 20e,f. Under a certain low incident power density of 2 × 104 mW cm−2, photoresponsivity has an enhancement with the state from OFF to ON, i.e., back gate potential (Vg) from 0 to 30 V. The increased photoresponsivity is attributed to the application of gate potential, which raises the Fermi level of graphene and causes a shrunken graphene–WS2 Schottky barrier height (ΦSB). It is obvious that photoresponsivity has different response trends to incident power density in both OFF and ON states. When Vg is 0 V, photoinduced charge transfer in the heterostructured regions leads to n-doping graphene, increasing the Fermi level of graphene, whereas when Vg is large, the effect of light on the Fermi level is weakened.
Furthermore, 2D materials can also be used to detect gas. Jung et al. reported a line patterned MoS2/rGO thin film with the ability to detect NO2 gas by soft lithography patterning.[160] The distribution of MoS2/rGO lines is very uniform with a width of 500 µm and a thickness of 10 nm. When the line array is transferred onto a poly-ethylene terephthalate film, its transmittance is up to 93%, higher than that of MoS2/rGO sheet without patterns. The device sensitivity is confirmed by the change rate of current at five different NO2 concentrations. By the reason of charge carrier transferring between NO2 gas and MoS2/rGO film, this line patterned MoS2/rGO film, with the sensitivity higher than that of pure rGO film, is able to detect a minimum NO2 concentration of 0.15 ppm. Experimentally, the flexible film retains its characteristics when the bending radius is 14 mm.

sections.heading: 5.3. Switching
sections.text:
The resonance behavior of patterned material is an effective route to enhance the light–matter interaction. Lee et al. reported
an electrically controllable system based on graphene, as shown in Figure 22a,b.[161] Metallic wire electrodes embedded in polymeric substrates are situated on both sides of the graphene deposited hexagonal metallic arrays. An electrically controlled hysteretic behavior with the corresponding Fermi level of graphene is demonstrated in Figure 22c. The Fermi level is dynamically tuned by the gate voltage, and thus the carrier density. As short pulse signals of +300 V (erase) and −300 V (write) are applied to switch terahertz waves, the transmission state at a fixed frequency T(f0) with a retention time of 20 min is recorded in Figure 22d. This indicates an electrically controlled photonic memory effect. Such switchable memory operation originates from the charge trap at defects or grain boundaries on graphene and adsorbed H2O molecules on substrate.
MoS2-coated arrays prepared by drop-casting technology can serve as an ultrafast all-optical switching based on Fano resonances.[162] As shown in Figure 23a,b, a micrometer-sized terahertz asymmetric split ring array on a quartz substrate is coated by MoS2, which has the function of regulating capacitance of the gaps between the structures. The device presents sharp Fano resonance at 0.82 THz when there is no optical pump pulse fluences illuminating on the patterned material system (Figure 23c). When the incident pump power is up to 254 µJ cm−2, abundant photoexcited charge carriers are generated in MoS2, increasing its photoconductivity and decreasing the capacitance. Then the Fano resonance peak disappears, tuned to off state in Figure 23d. The fast charge carrier relaxation leads to ultrafast switching of hundred picoseconds.
A similar Fano resonance switch was also realized by an exciton–plasmon coupling system, consisting of CVD-grown MoS2 monolayers and a single Au nanodisk about 60 nm in radius.[163] Under incident white light, the strong Fano resonance results from the coupling between the Au plasmon and MoS2 exciton. sections.heading: 5.4. Modulators
sections.text:
Patterned 2D materials have unique advantages in real-time tunable devices, due to the fact that conductivity of 2D materials can be tuned by external excitation such as gate voltage and light illumination, as well as the response of device can be enhanced via the coupling between patterned structures. For example, Liu et al. designed a hybrid modulator with a monolayer graphene plasmonic resonator in the middle of the complementary splitring resonator (C-SRR) gap, as shown in Figure 24a,b.[164] The near-field strong coupling between graphene localized surface plasmon and C-SRR LC-resonance brings about two hybridized modes, i.e., a bonding mode at lower frequency and an antibonding mode at higher frequency in Figure 24c,d. The local field is significantly enhanced in contrast with only the graphene resonator or the C-SRR. As shown in Figure 24e, with the applied gate voltage, the Fermi energy rises, so does the
carrier density. The surface plasmon resonance at lower frequency gradually strengthens and exceeds the LC-resonance at higher frequency. Such hybrid device exhibits ≈60% transmission modulation with the speed over 40 MHz.
Based on this work, Yan et al. improved the performance of the modulator by separating graphene structures from the metallic resonators with a spacer thickness of d (Figure 24g).[165] Trade-offs between insertion loss, modulation depth, and speed are achieved in Figure 24f, with the optimal one close to the top right corner. The red dots represent the calculated values using a transmission-line model. The graphene conductivity is tuned from 0.15 to 1 mS by tailoring layer number, with d varying from 1 to 16.5 µm. Its modulation depth is more than ≈70% and insertion loss is lower than 5 dB. Furthermore, they also investigated the effect of the electric-field enhancement factor and the variation in equivalent capacitance on THz transmission. As d reduces, light–matter interaction enhances, whereas effective permittivity decreases (Figure 24h). All of these factors dominate the figures of merit for modulators.
Investigations are extended to the MoS2 by Arezoomandan et al., indicating that other 2D materials beyond graphene can be used to build modulators.[166] Modulation depth of MoS2/ metal hybrid structure is higher than that of bare MoS2 film, due to the near-field enhancement of the patterned structure. The device exhibits <3 dB insertion loss because the possibility of lowest conductivity is near zero.

sections.heading: 5.5. Polarization Converters
sections.text: Polarization converters are used to modulate the electromagnetic wave front. Patterned 2D materials can produce structure- and wavelength-dependent phase shifts, which is promising for controlling the electromagnetic wave front. A periodically patterned graphene nanocrosses is proposed in infrared regime to dynamically tune anomalous refraction for circularly polarized waves.[167] The conversion efficiency is high and dynamically tuned by controllable Fermi energy of graphene. Another work is using graphene loaded plasmonic metasurfaces to dynamically modulate polarization state of electromagnetic wave in mid infrared regime, including circularly polarized wave and two orthogonally polarized wave.[168] The switchable gate voltage on graphene activates each polarization state. Compared with metallic polarization converters, the device composed of two crossed graphene nanoribbons supporting surface plasmons has a smaller size by 80 times.[169] The ultrathin device not only selects specific polarization states, but also generates higher-order harmonics.

sections.heading: 5.6. Gratings
sections.text: Single- or few-layer of MoS2 with high refractive index has giant elastic scattering efficiency making it possible to realize light manipulation.[170] Optical microscope images and atomic force microscopy images of MoS2 gratings with different layers are shown in Figure 25. Experimentally, the corresponding maximal grating efficiencies are 0.3%, 0.8%, and 10.1% for one layer (1L), two layers (2L), and eight layers (8L), respectively. It also gives the value of other materials for comparison, including SiO2, graphene, and Au. Scattering efficiency is governed by the electric field strength inside a material, where the refractive index has a positive role. Since MoS2 has a larger index, its maximum grating efficiency is higher than those of other materials. In addition, replacing with metal substrate can further improve the efficiency of MoS2 grating with a calculated value up to 23.7%.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
2D materials, as emerging stars, are always catching researcher’s eyes owing to their properties. For example, band structure is easy to be modulated by layer number, stacking sequence, functional groups, etc.[33,42,60] Electron transport way and efficiency are governed by the layered structure, thickness, groups, and defects.[46] Surface plasmonic resonance behaviors are directly observed from optical nanoimaging or ultrahigh resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy.[50,137] High frequency dielectric and optical properties are revealed
increasingly.[52,151] These lay a solid foundation for functional devices. Patterning enables 2D materials to release more vitality in applications by geometry-dependent physical effects, which can be used to easily modulate electromagnetic functions.
With unique features of each material, patterned 2D materials are suitable for the development of different functions. Patterned graphenes have been successfully used to fabricate electromagnetic attenuators, photodetectors, photoelectric switches, electromagnetic wave modulators, and polarization converters, due to variable electronic structures achieved by the bandgap engineering. MXenes, as a large family, present various properties, through the arrangement of different elements, structures, as well as the types of terminations. When designing devices based on patterned MXenes, we can not only draw on the experience of graphene devices, but also consider its own feature, such as three orders of transmission shield enhancement mentioned above.[21] For patterned MoS2 and WS2, related devices hold great designability, derived from their large absorption coefficient, tunable optical emission, huge exciton binding energy, and unique band structure from direct bandgap of monolayer to indirect bandgap of multilayer.[65,68,163,171] Another typical 2D material, black phosphorus possesses the obvious anisotropy and adjustable direct bandgap, endowing its device with pronounced optical response at high frequencies.

In general, devices constructed by patterned 2D materials have a bright future. They are beckoning toward industrialization, and commercialization is just around the corner. Devices will tend to be specially customized, and then providing customers with more freedom to choose. However, the reality is less than satisfactory, such as limitations of pristine material, finite methods in the preparing patterned structures, poor performance of packaged-devices, gap between embryonic devices and practical applications, etc.
Pristine 2D material is not perfect or desired, needing to be doped and heterogeneous to regulate its performance. For example, graphene is a zero bandgap material so that can not be switched between insulation and conduction. MXenes are relatively brittle, limiting its applications.[172,168] The mobility of MoS2 is not high enough to make it competitive in the crowded electronics market. Black phosphorus is not stable and is easily oxidized in air. These affect the comprehensive performance of prinstine 2D materials. Nowadays, a crystal engineering has made great progress on improving 2D materials, but it is not nearly enough and is necessary to continue research further.
Patterning as an effective strategy has remarkable effect. For example, He+ ion beam is used to realize high precision milling and atomic scale defect implantation, affecting the electronic properties of materials.[96] Self-assembly method based on atomic and molecular interaction force builds arrays of nanodots, nanoribbons, etc.[97,98] Nanoimprint lithography destroys atomic/molecular bonds in specific areas by mechanical force, and constructs geometries on a large scale.[102] These technologies have evolved well, spawning the diversification of fabrication technologies. However, ever-growing requirements propose more challenges for fabrication technologies, especially in more precise control of patterns. Atomic layer deposition and molecular layer deposition, with modulation of atomic-scale thickness, may be one of the optimal choices for precision fabrication.
Furthermore, devices made of patterned 2D materials have many unsolved problems, including stability, longevity, and overall performance. Real-time control of electromagnetic wave is always the most significant direction for designing devices. In addition to applied external voltage and incident laser power, thermal stimulation, magnetic actuation, and so on, can be referenced to engage in dynamically responses. Moreover, devices that meet the higher requirements of customers with multiple functions are still rare, especially in the electromagnetic field.

Geometric structures based on such crystals increase the freedom to manipulate electromagnetic wave, giving 2D materials infinite vitality. Recently, micro–nano devices integrated with patterned graphene, MXenes, MoS2, WS2, or black phosphorus are refreshing human being’s cognition, pushing micro–nano devices into a new level.[19–24] However, there is still broad space for improvement. Designing a high-performance micro–nano device remains a great challenge. Selecting materials based on the intrinsic nature, arranging layout, tailoring patterned structures, choosing fabrication methods, as well as knowing physical mechanism of devices are all key links in designing a prominent device. Intellectualization, multifunction, automation, or high integration is an inevitable trend in various devices. Reasonable utilization of physical effects to improve performance, optimize figure of merit, and integrate multiple functionalities are becoming the theme of micro–nano devices. Herein, we start from the crystal and electronic structures of several typical 2D materials to summarize the available physical effects and electromagnetic response behaviors. We highlight the progress in preparing patterned 2D materials, and emphasize the mechanism of the micro–nano devices to broaden the horizons for designing devices. Finally, we predict future directions of fabrication techniques and point out the problems in current devices.
